title: Euro 2020: Bulgarian stewards 'removed bibs before racially abusing England's black players'
text:
At least 20 Bulgarian stewards and stadium staff removed their official bibs before racially abusing England's black players on Tuesday night, it has been claimed.

Onlookers from football's anti-discrimination body Fare, as reported by The Times, were at the Vasil Levski Stadium as a series of racist chants and actions came from the stands.

And now, incredibly, it has emerged that it wasn't just fans of the team that were seen racially abusing the likes of Raheem Sterling and Tyrone Mings, but also technical staff.

There were two breaks in play in Sofia after racist chanting was reported to the match officials

The behaviour of some Bulgaria fans was met with widespread outrage and condemnation

Groups in the home section of the stadium were caught on camera performing Nazi salutes and monkey chants during England's 6-0 win over Bulgaria in Sofia.

Campaigners have since called for UEFA to expel the country from Euro 2020 qualifying in the aftermath of the disgraceful scenes.

Although Bulgaria cannot qualify directly through their group, as it stands they are in position to occupy a play-off spot in their attempts to reach the 2020 finals.

Pavel Klymenko, Fare's Eastern European specialist, told the Times: 'We believe and are calling for the Bulgarian FA to be kicked out of the Euro 2020 competition. UEFA should make an example of them, the legal armoury is there.

'Our observers told us they saw at the beginning of the game at least 20 people entered wearing the bibs of technical staff, took them off and just joined the fans.

The UEFA racism protocol was followed and reached stage two of three during the first half

Bulgarian fans with hoods and face masks, some of them with 'hooligans' printed on their shirts, head for the exits after the second stoppage on Monday evening

UEFA'S THREE-STEP PROTOCOL 1 - The referee will speak to the stadium announcer and demand the halting of racist behaviour. 2 - If it continues, the referee can take the players off the field into the dressing rooms for a period of time and the stadium announcer will make another address. 3 - If it still continues, the match will be abandoned.

'They are basically employed as stadium staff. That is not that rare in eastern Europe — many hooligan group members are connected to a club as security staff or stewards.

'Everyone knew exactly where in the stadium the problems were going to happen, yet there was not any screening of the fans. This is just negligence.

'The Bulgarian FA president Borislav should step down, the organisation of this match has been shambolic and his posturing and lack of leadership has made things worse.'

Klymenko's comments about the FA president were echoed by the country's own Prime Minister Boyko Borissov.

Borissov said Tuesday night's events were 'unacceptable', and the country's sports minister Krasen Kralev said: 'After the recent events, having in mind the whole state of football and last night's incidents, the prime minister has ordered me from today to suspend any relations with the BFU, including financial ones, until the resignation of Borislav Mihaylov.'
